data.title: 'This Bike Is A Pipe Bomb' defendant convicted of disturbing the peace
data.meta_description: A 53-year-old Kalamazoo man was convicted Tuesday of disturbing the peace for having a homemake sticker on his bicycle that read "this bike is a pipe bomb."
data.text:
KALAMAZOO, MI

-- A 53-year-old Kalamazoo man was convicted Tuesday of disturbing the peace for having a homemade sticker on his

."

Gordon Holdridge parked the bike in front of the U.S. Federal Building in downtown Kalamazoo while he and a friend were staging an Occupy Kalamazoo protest on June 13.

Holdridge was convicted in a jury trial Tuesday in Kalamazoo County District Court in front of Judge Paul Bridenstine. He was sentenced to 20 hours of community service, plus fines and costs, which haven't been totaled yet, said Carrie Klein, chief assistant prosecutor for the Kalamazoo County Prosecutor's Office.

Holddridge was originally arrested for making a false bomb threat, a felony, but the prosecutor's office reduced the charge to disturbing the peace, a misdemeanor.

Holdridge said the sticker is a reference to

and that he forgot the sticker was even on the bike. But he didn't tell police that.

"I didn't enlighten them. I was naive," Holdridge told the Kalamazoo Gazette in July. A 53-year-old Kalamazoo resident, Holdridge is unemployed and on disability.

When Holdridge and his friend were staging the protest, a federal security guard noticed that Holdridge's bike had the sticker and she called police.

A SWAT team showed up to investigate. Holdridge told the officers that the sign was "was just a joke" and that he prefers comedy to make a point. He also said that pipe bombs "can be purchased at Wal-Mart for $99.99."

Holdridge was arrested and spent the night in the Kalamazoo County Jail.

Holdridge's attorney, John Targowski of Kalamazoo, has said the prosecutor offered a plea bargain that included dropping the charge in exchange for 40 hours of community service and psychological counseling.
